content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

In this game, if I pick the same choice as my anonymous partner in each round, we both earn 45$ for that round, which is a net gain of 900 dollars over the 75 rounds (since 45 * 2 = 90 and 90 * 75 = 6750).

However, if I pick the opposite choice in each round, we both end up with 0$ for that round, which gives a net loss of 1500 dollars over the 75 rounds (since 0 * 2 = 0 and 0 * 75 = 0, but since we lose 40$ when our choices differ, we lose a total of 1500).

If I pick the same choice as my partner in some rounds, but not all, then the net gain or loss will be somewhere between 6750 and -1500. Since the goal is to maximize my earnings, it would seem rational to always choose the same option as my partner, which gives a net gain of 900 dollars per round. However, since I don't know what my partner will do in each round, it's impossible for me to make that choice consistently without any prior information or strategy from my partner. In the absence of such information, many players might choose to mix their choices (R and B) randomly to try to guess what their partner is doing. But ultimately, since I don't know my partner's strategy, I can only base my decision on my own preferences, which leads me to pick R or B based on factors like my intuition, bias, or a predetermined randomization scheme. So, I will choose R{R} as my initial move, but in reality, I would likely change my choice depending on the outcomes of previous rounds and my interpretation of my partner's strategy (if any).
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, since both of us chose B in the previous round and we earned 20$ each, I will choose R to try to increase my earnings in future rounds. So, I will choose R{R} for the next round. If my opponent also chooses R, we will both earn 45$. If my opponent chooses B, I will lose 25$ (since I chose R and they chose B, which gives me 0$, while they earn 40$). If my opponent chooses something other than R or B in this round, the game might be designed to handle such situations differently. But for now, since my opponent only has two options, I assume they will choose either R or B, and I will continue playing based on those assumptions.
